import React from 'react'; import {Link} from "react-router-dom"; import Home from '../images/Home.png'; import iOSDeposit from '../images/iOS Check Deposit - Step 1 (1).png'; import Moodboard from '../images/moodboard.png'; import Objectives from '../images/project objectives.png'; import Sitemap from '../images/Sitemap.png' import TutorialPage from '../images/Tutorial Page (1).png'; import TradeProjectImage from '../images/trade project image.png' function BranchPilotProject() { return(

Transaction migration pilot: Convincing Truist's branch customers to transact digitally

5 min read  //  February 2023 - April 2023

My Role

Design lead. Oversaw and had final say on the design work of a UI designer, a content designer, and myself. Served as the point of contact for design.

Project Team

UI Designer, Content Designer, Business Strategist, Product Manager, App Developer, Engineering Manager, IT Support

Tools I Used

Figma, Miro, Tailwind CSS

Figma Prototype

Background

A core pillar of Truist's strategy is to increase adoption of digital banking. After all, it's less expensive for the bank and more time-efficient for consumers if they transact on their phone rather than in a branch.

In early 2023, a team had formed to think of ways to do just this. Specifically, the team sought to make changes in branches that would encourage visitors to do straightforward banking tasks (such as depositing a check and withdrawing money) on their phone or an ATM.

Their main idea was simple - if we teach branch visitors about the things that they can do digitally, and then show them how to do it, they'll be more likely to do those things digitally. I was brought, along with one other designer, to turn this idea into a functional app that would be loaded on iPads and shipped to branches.

Working under a tight timeline

We didn't have long to do it either. The team wanted to debut the app by the first week of April. Factoring in the engineering team's timeline to build it, we had just under 6 weeks to design the entire thing.

Hitting the ground running

To work quickly, we would need to clearly understand the scope of work. How will teammates and clients interact with these tutorials? What tasks should be covered? Are there existing tutorials with content we can leverage? These are just a few of the many questions I asked during our kickoff meetings.

A figma slide I created following our first few meetings to track the project. It's messy but it got the job done!

Initial ideation and brainstorming

After gaining a solid understanding of the project objectives, our next step was to come up was to brainstorm possible solutions. We spent a few days gathering inspiration. We read articles on how to design effective informational overlays, read through the entirety of the very dated tutorials that Truist already had, and took dozens of screenshots from Dribble.

We compiled the various articles and screenshots we'd gathered into a moodboard, shown here.

Delegating the work

We would need to work efficiently to complete everything before our deadline. While I worked on the information architecture and interaction design, the other designer gathered screenshots and videos for the tutorials and started working on visual design ideas.

Knowing this project would be content-heavy, I recruited the assistance of a content designer I'd worked with previously. She wrote the instructional content within the tutorials based on the flows, screenshots, and videos we provided.

Information architecture: Nailing down navigation

Ensuring the tutorials could be easily found and navigated to was just as important as the tutorials themselves. I knew that teammates would be using the tutorials to help clients with specific tasks. To make it easy and intuitive for teammates to find tutorials, I organized them by tasks.

An early version of a site map I created. Having a dedicated app certainly enabled us to keep the IA simple! I choose a relatively flat hierarchy to ensure all tutorials could be found quickly from the home screen.

The final version of the home page remained faithful to the site map, though we added a device filter so teammates could quickly find all tutorials for a specific device.

Designing the tutorials

The tutorials themselves came together quickly once we had assets to populate them with. Several factors influenced the design:

Factor #1

Our target audience skewed older. The content needed to be understandable by someone with limited technology proficiency.

Factor #2

Respect peoples' time. We wanted each tutorial to be able to be completed in 5 minutes or less.

I drew several low-fidelity wireframes, such as this one, to quickly explore ways of presenting the information.

Here's the final version. For each tutorial, we created a step for each action that a user needed to take to complete the task. Users could quickly navigate through those steps using the progress indicator, allowing them to follow along at their own pace.

Outcome

The pilot was a big success - teammates praised the ease of use of the app and the general usefulness of having iPads that they could use during conversations with clients. Shortly after the initial shipment of iPads were shipped out, the project was approved to be expanded to additional branches.

No user research?

I wanted to address this question since it's one that I was asked at several points during the design and build process (and one that you may naturally be wondering). Because of the tight timeline and the fact that this was a pilot project, I chose not to conduct any research.

Fitting user testing into our schedule would have meant sacrificing design time, and I felt that it was more important to deliver a great first experience using existing research and our design intuition. In addition, I knew that the feedback we would get from the pilot itself would be more realistic than any study we could've done in the time we had.

Thanks for reading!

); } export default BranchPilotProject;
